Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 09:27PM rferraris wrote: Angel, I had a drain for almost a year after my bilateral tram!  I can so relate to what you are feeling.  I have a seroma that originally started under my right arm and went al the way down in to my groin on the left side.  My PS cut it out three times, injected it with doxycillian 3 times and injected it with Tisseal.  Needless to say 20 months post-op I still have the waterbed effect going on in my belly.  I have stumped my PS, oncologist, bs and the immunoligist that treated me for staph (2x in less than 1 yr).  They cannot find any documentation on this lasting this long.  The latest thought is that it is actually lymph fluid filling in the pertineum (sp) cavity.  Unfortunately the only doctor that we can find that might know anything about this is the Upstate NY and I live in Central Georgia.   When my seroma was the largest (it is shrinking) I was very anemic and had to have weekly iron infusions.  I was borderline of needing a blood transfusion.  To me it would make sense that blood loss would cause anemia.   Stay positive!  It helps me to try to find some kind of humor in all of this!!  One of my girlfriends told me the other day that all of my docs should be paying me since they are learning so much off of me!!!

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 10:15PM rferraris wrote: You have to realize that those darn cancer cells are microscopic and we don't know exactly where they are.  Even though it sounds like you didn't have any lymph node involvement, what if there are cells brewing there?  Your treatment is YOUR decision.  Have you met with a medical oncologist yet to discuss treatment options?  I was at a conference for young women diagnosed with breast cancer under 40 and one of the major breast cancer guru's said that if you are HER2+ and receive Herceptin for 1 yr and make it 5 years after that without a recurrence, that your change of recurrence after that point in less than 1%.  Sounds like pretty good odds to me!

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 11:25PM rferraris wrote: I've been dealing with a seroma for over a year!  I've stumped them all here and have even been to Atlanta to Emory University.  I spent 90% of 2008 with either a JP drain or a penrose drain.  The few weeks that I didn't have a drain I would go in for weekly aspirations.  I'm down to going about once a month.  They can explain what is going on but not why.  I am so tired of this and ready to move on.  I cannot have my modification for my reconstruction until I've done 6 months with no fluid. My immunologist think that my lymphatics have been messed up and there isn't anyone locally that can do some kind of lymphatics test.  I think I may win an award for the longest healing time for a bilateral tram (15 months so far!!)

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 10:14PM rferraris wrote: Jenns I was 35 when I started chemo in 2006.  I was stage III, invasive ductal carcinoma & lobular.  I had 13 positive nodes so I did have to hard stuff but I made it through!  I too was ER+ but was HER2-.  Waiting a couple of weeks will be fine.  That will give her body time to heal from your surgery.  If you need chemo you need to be strong when you start.  I'd bet that they will at least give her Herceptin since you were HER2+.  I didn't have it but my friend did.  From what I understand it was a breeze compared to everything else.   Best wishes & stay positive!! Rachel

Re pancreatic cancer...My best friends father just passed away from pancreatic cancer two weeks after his diagnosis.  Pancreatic is the 4th leading cause of death and unfortunately, by the time you have a diagnosis it is to late.  There hasn't been any advances in pancreatic cancer is 30 years.  Think of how far we've come in 30 years with breast cancer research.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 02:59AM rferraris wrote: Someone asked if I work for Komen and I do not. I do spend a large amount of my time volunteering in my local affiliate working health fairs, speaking to other survivors & newly diagnosed families, giving out educational material, etc. Another one of the hats that I wear with our affiliate is Public Policy chair. Komen has worked very hard in educating our National & State leaders on the importance of funding for access to equal treatment for all, early detection/screening & translational research (out of the lab and to the patient). I take it very personal when someone starts bashing Komen for what they "haven't" done without acknowledging what we have done. Do people not realize this organization started with a promise to a dying sister a little over 25 years ago to end breast cancer forever? Nancy Brinker started Komen for the Cure in her living room with $200 and a shoe box a names. Please read Nancy & Susan's story from the komen.org website. In the last 25 years Komen has funded more than $1 BILLION in research. Who else has done that? We've committed another $1 BILLION in the next 10 years. FlaLady I'm sorry that you feel like you were treated like a lab rat. Where you forced in to a clinical? Shame on the clinic where you received treatment if they did not inform you properly of all the risks. I recently met a girl my age who was diagnosed about the same time I was. Her Grandmother was in a clinical trail 20+ years ago for Adriamycian. Because of her Grandmother's unselfishness, she helped save her life and so many others, years before her Granddaughters diagnosis. My cancer was too advanced to do a clinical because of my young age (stage III @ 35) but I'd do anything in my power so that another young family doesn't have to face the battle that mine has been on for the last 2 years. Also, Komen's budget is nowhere near $40 billion. Komen has granted out $1 billion since 1982, and it's yearly budget is around $275 million. $200 million of that went to breast cancer research, breast cancer screening, and treatment. 75% of the money raised by the local affiliates stays in the local service area. But, before any money is granted, a grant request must be made and presented to the grant review board. If the grant review board agrees with the grant request, it is forwarded to the local Komen board for a vote. Sometimes, the board will turn down a request because there are additional questions that need to be addressed. But if your local affiliate is not spending the money that you see fit, then get involved with them. Don't just stand on the sidelines and point fingers. You can't just call a local Komen affiliate and ask for money. The affiliates want to make sure every dollar they spend is accounted for, and goes toward the mission. The process I detailed above ensures that. Again, I would encourage you to get involved with your local affiliate and help them make those decisions as to where the money is to be spent. By the way, there is no Komen "state board". Each affiliate is their own autonomous organization.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 02:07PM rferraris wrote: I am going tomorrow for a doplar in my legs.  She is ordering this to be on the safe side because I have three blood clots (2 in rt arm and one under the scar of where my port was) but I know the pain has nothing to do with a blood clot.  Today I was volunteering for Komen at a health fair and the booth next to us had a bone density screening machine.  I am very close to osteopenia.  The radialogist that did the test didn't like my score because of my age (38) and that I am already taking 1000 IU of Calcium.  I will take that sheet with me tomorrow when I see my oncologist.  I have a feeling that a full bone density scan is in my near future.
